black.content: This week’s lab results brought you by _.
Science: The only endeavor in which studying _ is respectable.
The next pandemic virus will emerge from _.
_ is why there aren't enough women in the sciences.
Elon Musk’s next company will focus on _.
_ :  An under-emphasized lab necessity.
_ taught me all I know about science.
_ : soul-crushing, but necessary for publication.
The latest superstar professor hired works on _.
The best way to obtain publication-quality data is to use _.
Applied for a postdoc, all I got was this lousy _.
_ is why it always takes an extra five minutes to get the computer projector working.
Oh, those are just mice with _.
What aspects of STEM public outreach are audiences most clamoring for? _
When I opened the incubator this morning, I found _.
Life would be so much better if you could get funding for (studying) _.
I got a spot in the lab due to my research on _.
My PCR didn’t work due to _.
I couldn’t finish my proposal because I was delayed by _.
Congratulations! Your fellowship includes a stipend and _.
Your gut microbiota can help you withstand _.
My Ph.D. degree should really be in working with _.
The mysterious residue on the lab counter was _.
Scientific breakthroughs are often a result of _.
It’s been said that _ causes autism.
I can’t wait until I never have to work with _ again.
_ : Why I chose a career in science.
Disneyland recently had an outbreak of _.
The next Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine will be awarded for _.
Tested _ - results inconclusive.
_ is/are a valid reason to postpone your experiments today.
Science has become much more competitive since _ were included in grant applications.
I knew my Ph.D. defense wasn’t going well when _ became a heated topic of discussion.
What contaminated my cell cultures? _
_ : How do they work?
I published my first paper in the Journal of _.
Why is my bench sticky? _
_ probably isn’t a valid travel expense.
_ is an acceptable substitute for template DNA in your reaction.
When alone at night in lab, I like to play with _.
Your advisor’s lab pet peeve is _.
_ make/s the frustration of research worthwhile.
Before centrifuging, never forget to include _ as a balance.
What really killed the dinosaurs? _
After I defended, my advisor gave me _.
My PCR didn’t work due to _ contaminating the reaction.
_ : Don’t go to a conference without it/them.
Soon, I will accomplish my life long goal of researching _.
After getting tenure, the professor celebrated by buying _ for the lab.
"It's trivial!" said the Professor. "It obviously happens because of _."
_ is the newest explanation for carcinogenesis.
I will be required to dissect 500 _ to complete my thesis.
The next target of gene therapy should be _.
_. #overlyhonest- methods.
In what’s being hailed as a major breakthrough, sciences have synthesized _ in the lab.
To increase its impact factor, Nature published a special issue about _.
In hindsight, I probably shouldn’t have put _ in the autoclave.
While mercifully rare, there is no known cure for _.
Hey there, young scientists! Put on your gloves and lab coats because today we’re learning about _!
We knew our grant didn’t get funded when the reviewers didn’t understand our methods regarding _.
_ is why it takes so long to obtain a Ph.D.
Publish about _ or perish.
A PI’s favorite thing in the entire world is _.
A study published in Science this week found that _ is good for you in small doses.

white: The grad student that needs sensitivity training.
Excessive amounts of time playing with parafilm.
Freaking out about the next emerging disease.
A freakish independently replicating strain of AAV.
Getting really worried about global warming for a few seconds.
A grad student with nothing to lose.
The grad student who has been in the department longer than all known faculty.
The majority of lab members who have GFP antibodies.
Quick naps in the dark room.
Experiments that require you to go to the nuclear pharmacy.
Someone who borrowed your pipettes and never returned them.
Prancing about the BSL-3 lab in a bunny suit.
Using the sharps container as a piñata.
Not being able to access PubMed due to a government shutdown.
Free food from seminars you don’t really care about.
Tense TSA detainments due to chemicals on your shoes.
Science jokes not even your lab mates would understand.
The unlabeled bottle that everyone is too scared to throw away.
Singing or dancing in the lab when you think no one is around.
The decision between studying, another experiment, or getting enough sleep.
Reprogrammed stem cells exhibiting atavistic characteristics.
Pipetting clear liquids into other clear liquids.
The postdoc that always says controversial things.
Decades of lost samples due to an accidentally unplugged -80 °C freezer.
That quiet postdoc whose project is a mystery.
The flickering lights in the conference room that keep you awake.
New viruses harvested from angry koalas.
The never-ending quest for 'as described previously'.
A mouse that simply refuses to die.
A concerning fuzzy mass in the buffer.
Mice with tumors on their butts.
Replacing the polymerase enzyme with rancid komodo dragon saliva.
The custodian that is your best friend.
The Scoville scale of pepper hotness.
The faculty member who should attend responsible conduct of research classes.
Coffee, the essential elixir of life.
Getting trapped in the BSL-3 lab due to faulty negative pressure systems.
A research monkey smarter than the lab assistant.
A superfluous number of flow cytometry lasers.
Windows automatically installing updates minutes before your thesis defense.
Stray kittens found walking home from lab.
Catastrophic failure of the BSL-3 air filtration system.
The lab tech you can never find when you need them.
Mice that receive better healthcare than the students.
Extreme hunger because you forgot to eat while sciencing all day.
A computer older than all of the grad students combined.
Secret steps in protocols that make all the difference.
The person on the floor who never smiles.
The sixth year grad student forced to drink cell media for sustenance.
Results that change every time you perform the experiment.
The only antibody that works but is no longer made.
The glory of manuscript acceptance on your first try.
Hunger strike when I don't get tenure.
The last 200 μl of the most important buffer in the kit.
Being knowledgeable in a narrow field no one cares about or understands.
Illegible lab notebooks from long gone lab members.
Awkward dancing at conference social events.
Lots of alone time in the microscopy room.
The sixth revision of your manuscript.
The lab mate who is a mess.
Evidence that there really is a god.
The control mouse you smuggled home as a pet.
A mouse growing a human ear on its back.
Falling in love with your research animals.
Watching Netflix with your animals because they need 'enrichment'.
That new virus coming out of China.
The funky smell in the animal facility.
Model organisms that glow in the dark.
A monkey infected with Ebola that seems perfectly fine.
Existential despair induced by repetitive failure.
The PI who unexpectedly left in the middle of your Ph.D. :(.
Ultracentrifuge tubes as fragile as your ego.
Baby talking to your samples to encourage them.
New viruses discovered by coughing on your labmate’s plate of primary cells.
Long rambling questions after a conference talk.
A massive box used to ship a tiny tube of reagent.
Weather so cold you can store your samples outside.
Bleach spots on your favorite shirt.
Late night, coffee fueled grant ideas.
